sub_title: Co-Director Impact: Center against Human Trafficking and Sexual Violence in Conflict
summary:
Anne-Marie de Brouwer (Ph.D., LL.M., LL.M.) is co-founder and co-director of IMPACT: Center against Human Trafficking and Sexual Violence in Conflict. She is also the co-founder and chair of the Mukomeze Foundation, which aims to improve the lives of women and men who survived sexual violence during the 1994 Genocide against the Tutsi in Rwanda, and co-owner of Bèkske: Rwandan Empowerment Coffee. She is furthermore a member of the Team of Experts of the UK’s Preventing Sexual Violence in Conflict Initiative (PSVI). From 2008-2019 she was a Research Fellow with the International Victimology Institute Tilburg (INTERVICT), from 2008-2016 an Associate Professor in international criminal law at Tilburg University, and from 2006-2007 an Associate Legal Officer at the NGO Women’s Initiatives for Gender Justice in The Hague. 

Her main areas of research, teaching and interest include international criminal law and procedure, victims’ rights, gender, victimology, conflict-related sexual violence, human trafficking and transitional justice. De Brouwer is the author of over 70 publications, including the book/PhD “Supranational Criminal Prosecution of Sexual Violence: The ICC and the Practice of the ICTY and the ICTR (Oxford-Antwerp: Intersentia, 2005)”, for which she received the Max van der Stoel Human Rights Award 2006. Other (co-edited) works include “The Men Who Killed Me: Rwandan Survivors of Sexual Violence (Douglas & McIntyre, 2009), “Sexual Violence as an International Crime: Interdisciplinary Approaches (Intersentia, 2013), “ELGAR Companion to the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda (Edward Elgar Publishing Ltd, 2016)”, and "And I Live On: The Resilience of Rwandan Genocide Survivors of Sexual Violence (Wolf Legal Publishers, 2019)". 

In 2013, she was awarded a Royal distinction (“Dame”/"Knight") in the Order of Oranje-Nassau for her academic and societal work concerning conflict-related sexual violence.
